metadata.title: 7 Key Differences Between Machine Learning Engineers And Researchers (Salaries Included) | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 7 Key Differences Between Machine Learning Engineers And Researchers (Salaries Included)
metadata.description: Artificial Intelligence is currently an interesting industry to be involved in, and Machine Learning practitioners are the ‘cool kids’ now. But even amongst the ‘cool kids’, there is a clear…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: salary for a Machine Learning Researcher
salary for a Machine Learning Engineer

all_paragraphs: Artificial Intelligence is currently an interesting industry to be involved in, and Machine Learning practitioners are the ‘cool kids’ now.

But even amongst the ‘cool kids’, there is a clear distinction between the groups of Machine Learning practitioners, more specifically a distinction between those who research solutions and those who engineer solutions.
That been said, this distinction isn’t as clear as it should be.
Highlighting the differences between both roles could empower you with the information required to make better academic and career choices.
Before we proceed further, it’s important to note that I’m utilizing the term Machine Learning Engineer and Researcher as an umbrella term for the following roles:
A Machine Learning Engineer’s role involves the implementation of machine learning algorithms and models within implemented software/hardware solutions.
A Machine Learning Researcher’s role is concerned with the advancement of a specific or niche subject domain within machine learning.
ML researchers are often educated to a PhD level. They tend to be individuals with strong academic and research-focused backgrounds.
They also hold advanced degrees in Computer-Science related topics.
The majority of ML Engineers hold Master’s degrees, and only a few ML Engineers have undertaken Ph.Ds.
To get an understanding of the academic backgrounds of ML Engineers and Researchers, I utilized LinkedIn.
I went over a number of profiles of individuals who have ‘Machine Learning Researcher’, ‘Machine Learning Scientist’ or ‘Machine Learning Engineer’ in their job titles.
An ML Engineer’s deliverable is usually an engineered solution with a machine learning model that enables the execution of a set of tasks in an automated, efficient, or creative manner.
For an ML Engineer, the end product or deliverable could be a piece of software where functionalities powered by a method of machine learning.

Whereas, An ML Researcher’s deliverable tends to be a well-written research paper that includes details of experiments and investigative study undertaken to achieve a specific advancement or improvement of performance/accuracy in a particular machine learning related task.

An ML Researcher’s end product would be the recorded exploration of newly found discoveries, improvement or analysis, that is submitted and accepted into international conferences and scientific journals.
Salary is probably the key difference a lot of readers will be most interested in.
Machine Learning practitioners are in high demand, and the salary offered for ML related roles reflects this.
For example, take this article by the NY Times that mentions the wages of top AI researchers exceeding $1 Million.
Obviously, within high demanding industries, there are individuals in the top 0.01 percentile that command a large sum of salary.
But let me give some stats that apply to the majority.
In the United Kingdom, the average salary for a Machine Learning Researcher for the period backdating six months from the 3rd of April 2020 is £57,500.
Meanwhile, the average salary for a Machine Learning Engineer for the same period is £68,750.
So in the UK, there is a clear £10,000 margin between the two ML roles.
According to LinkedIn, the average base salary for ML Researchers in the US is $143,000(110 ML Researchers).
For ML Engineers in the US, this figure reduces to $125,000, but it includes more data from over 900 ML Engineers.
Personally, from my observation of people I’ve studied and worked with within the AI industry, monetary motivations are not primary.
The opportunity of exposure and knowledge seems more appealing to groups within my cohort, including myself.
Simply kept, young machine learning engineers could be more concerned with bragging rights and clout, than monetary incentives.
Who wouldn’t want to be a Machine Learning Engineer or Researcher at one of the FAANG companies, regardless of the pay?
Do consider that stats are not reflective of the true salary expectation of the industry, they should be used as guidelines and not the absolute truth.
ML Engineers need to see the bigger picture. ML Researchers require a more focused perspective.

Engineering within software is a discipline that requires an understanding of the components that are associated with a product, process, or pipeline. This is crucial as engineers are tasked with the responsibility of integrating several components.
Here are a few items a typical ML Engineer tackles during a project:
On the other hand, an ML Researcher’s scope of work tends to be very defined. The ML Researcher role is a very focused discipline.

ML Researchers do not need to worry significantly about how ML models or algorithms perform in a variety of environments. ML Researcher’s work tends to be very problem-focused and specific. They’re usually tasked with either finding a new method of addressing a problem or improving the performance and accuracy of previous devised solutions.
Job role descriptions and requirements for ML Researchers are precise and focused within a particular area of Machine Learning.
Typical job role requirements for an ML Researcher include the following:
Typical job role requirements for an ML Engineer include the following:
ML Researchers can engineer, and ML Engineer do research.

Being a Machine Learning practitioner also means being well versed in modern-day’s software libraries and hardware. Machine Learning itself if a multidisciplinary field, and job titles do not usually paint the full picture of the role.

To illustrate my point, ML Researchers could have a 70/30 split between actual researching and engineering. And not the flip side of the coin, ML Engineers typically have a separation of 70/30 between engineering and researching.

I can attest to split between researching and engineering for an ML Engineer, as within my current role as a Computer Vision Engineer, I spend a lot of time engineering ML models into solutions, such as websites or mobile applications. And at the same time, I dedicate a small amount of effort into searching PapersWithCode or ReserachGate for published research papers for particular problems I’m tackling.
I have to admit that there are several differences are not mentioned in this article, but a quick google search will provide some other differences.
Whichever career path you do choose to pursue, do acknowledge the fact that both roles require a tremendous amount of time and effort to obtain, but the benefits are rewarding.
To learn more about what it’s like being an ML Engineer, I have linked two articles that tell how my first day and month as a Computer Vision Engineer in a startup went.
